qas.question: What does immersive app stand for?

answers.text: the apps prior to the first official presentation of Windows 8

qas.question: What are apps after the introduction of Windows 8 called?

answers.text: vice president of Microsoft's development software division

qas.question: When did Windows Store apps become the real term for the apps?

plausible_answers.text: the apps prior to the first official presentation of Windows 8

qas.question: What does unimmersive app stand for?

plausible_answers.text: the apps prior to the first official presentation of Windows 8

qas.question: What doesn't immersive app stand for?
What are apps after the introduction of Windows 9 called?

plausible_answers.text: vice president of Microsoft's development software division

qas.question: When didn't Windows Store apps become the real term for the apps?

context: The term "Immersive app" had been used internally by Microsoft developers to refer to <a0_0><b4_0><b5_0>the apps prior to the first official presentation of Windows 8<b5_0/><b4_0/><a0_0/>, after which they were referred to as "<a1_0><b6_0>Metro-style apps<b6_0/><a1_0/>" in reference to the Metro design language. The term was phased out in August 2012; a Microsoft spokesperson denied rumors that the change was related to a potential trademark issue, and stated that "Metro" was only a codename that would be replaced prior to Windows 8's release. Following these reports, the terms "Modern UI-style apps", "Windows 8-style apps" and "Windows Store apps" began to be used by various Microsoft documents and material to refer to the new apps. In an interview on <a3_0><b8_0>September 12, 2012<b8_0/><a3_0/>, Soma Somasegar (<a2_0><b7_0>vice president of Microsoft's development software division<b7_0/><a2_0/>) confirmed that "Windows Store apps" would be the official term for the apps. An MSDN page explaining the Metro design language uses the term "Modern design" to refer to the language as a whole.
